407.source:
After losing two straight games, the Raiders looked to rebound at Qualcomm Stadium, facing a Chargers team coming off a big win at Indianapolis. The game started well for the Raiders; thanks to a muffed punt by Darren Sproles that was recovered by Hiram Eugene at the San Diego 18 yard line, and set up a 9-yard rushing touchdown by Jason Campbell. Scoring continued in the first quarter with a 4-yard pass from Campbell to Jacoby Ford; and gave the Raiders an early 14-0 lead over the Chargers.  The second quarter started with a 9-play, 48 yard drive that ended on a 39-yard field goal by Nate Kaeding, giving San Diego its first points of the game. Oakland answered with a rushing touchdown by Michael Bush, extending the lead to 21-3. The first half closed on a missed field goal by Kaeding. The second half started with a quite calm third quarter, who saw both teams playing good defense and a Raiders team suffering with penalties. The third quarter closed with another field goal by Kaeding, nearing the Chargers on the scoreboard 21-6. The fourth quarter saw the Chargers trying to mount a comeback with a 4-yard TD pass from Philip Rivers to Antonio Gates; but it was promptly closed by a 7-play, 62 yard drive that ended with a Darren McFadden 7 yard rushing TD. With the win, both Raiders and Chargers reached a 6-6 record, and still stayed behind the Chiefs by 2 games for the division lead. The Raiders also swept the season series from the Chargers for the first time since 2001, and snapped a seven-game losing streak at Qualcomm Stadium. The Raiders were favored by an impeding Chargers offense who struggled to control the game clock and establish a ground game; while the Raiders struggled with penalties and defensive miscues, mostly on the secondary.

Which player made and missed a field goal?
407.rationale: Nate Kaeding made and missed a field goal. This can be found in the article when it says "The second quarter started with a 9-play, 48 yard drive that ended on a 39-yard field goal by Nate Kaeding" and then again later: "third quarter closed with another field goal by Kaeding".

410.source:
Read this article and answer this question Patriots quarterback Tom Brady threw for a career second-best 466 yards, as he completed 38 of 59 pass attempts with three touchdown throws, as the Patriots were able to hold off a late Buffalo Bills rally thanks to their high-octane offense, giving the Patriots their first divisional win of the season. The match-up between the Bills and Patriots was highly anticipated in the week before the meeting. Both teams had won their first games of the new season and high expectations for the season ahead were falling on both teams, including the host team, who were led by new head coach and old Patriots' foe Rex Ryan (formerly of the New York Jets). The Guinness Book of World Records was invited to Ralph Wilson Stadium to see if the Bills' fans could break the decibel record for crowd noise that was set at Arrowhead Stadium by Kansas City Chiefs' fans in the season prior (coincidentally in a game that the Patriots also featured in as the away team). In a heated game-day atmosphere, the Bills took the opening kickoff and drove the ball 80-yards in ten plays, with rookie running back Karlos Williams scoring on a 2-yard run. Two possessions later, the Patriots, aided by completions of 16 and 36 yards to Aaron Dobson and Gronkowski respectively, raced 62 yards in only 5 plays, with Julian Edelman catching an 8-yard touchdown pass from Brady. After another Bills three-and-out, aided by a 28-yard punt return to the Bills 27 by Danny Amendola coupled with an unnecessary roughness penalty on the Bills, the Patriots need just two plays to go 13 yards and score on a 6-yard touchdown run by Dion Lewis, taking a 14-7 lead. On the ensuing Bills' drive, Tyrod Taylor was intercepted by Super Bowl hero Malcolm Butler, who returned it 9 yards to the Bills 30. The Patriots then marched 30 yards in just 5 plays, scoring on Brady's 6-yard touchdown pass to Gronkowski, extending the lead to 21-7. After a Bills punt, from the Bills 48, Lewis caught a 6-yard pass, but was stripped by Paul Brown with Corey Graham returning it 29 yards to the Patriots 33, but an unnecessary roughness penalty moved them back to the 48. After being forced to punt, the Patriots drove to the Bills 48, but on 4th-and-1 Brady fired an incomplete pass. The Bills finally scored again, racing 48 yards in four penalty marred plays, scoring on a 9-yard touchdown pass to Charles Clay, trimming the deficit to 21-13, after a missed PAT. The Patriots drove to the Bills 28 on their next drive and Stephen Gostkowski converted a 46-yard field goal, increasing the lead to 24-13. The Bills advanced the ball to the 50-yard line on the next drive, but Taylor was intercepted by Harmon a deep pass intended for wide receiver Sammy Watkins with 16 seconds remaining in the half. Brady took a knee on the ensuing drive, with the Patriots going into the half leading 24-13. The Patriots drove 77 yards on the opening drive, all the way to the Bills 3-yard line, but were forced to settle for a 21-yard field goal by Gostkowski, making the score 27-13. After a Bills punt, the Patriots raced 83 yards in 9 plays, with Brady capping off the drive with a 22-yard touchdown pass to a diving Edelman, growing the lead to 34-13. After a Bills three-and-out, the Patriots drove to the Bills 32 and Gostkowski upping the lead to 37-13 on a 50-yard field goal. As the game entered the fourth quarter and with many Bills fans already heading for the exits, the Bills were finally able to establish rhythm with their offense, as Taylor led Buffalo on a 10-play, 80-yard drive, bombing a 32-yard touchdown pass to wide receiver Robert Woods, with a failed two-point conversion, making the score 37-19.  The Patriots drove to the Bills 41 on their next drive, but failed to convert. The Bills quickly capitalized, racing 59 yards in only 7 plays, with Taylor running in a 7-yard touchdown, with a missed two-point conversion, trimming the deficit to just 37-25. On the second play of the ensuing Patriots drive, Brady was strip-sacked by Jerry Hughes , with Preston Brown recovering for the Bills at midfield. It only took two plays to cover 50 yards, with Taylor finding Watkins for a 24-yard touchdown, making the score just 37-32 after being down 37-13. As had been the theme throughout the day, the Bills' defense was unable to keep Brady and the Patriots' offense from marching up-and-down the field, and on their final drive, New England drove to the Bills 8 and Gostkowski upped the lead to 40-32 on his 26-yard field goal. On the Bills' first play of the Bills next drive, Taylor was intercepted for the third time of the day, this time by cornerback Logan Ryan at the 50-yard line on a long pass intended for Watkins. Brady kneeled on the ensuing drive, securing the 40-32 win. The Bills' fans failed to set the Guinness World Record for loudest crowd noise.
How many yards was the longest field goal?
410.rationale: The longest field goal was 50 yards, as shown in the passage.

413.source:
Write a question about the following article: Mount Vesuvius has erupted many times. The famous eruption in AD 79 was preceded by numerous others in prehistory, including at least three significantly larger ones, the best known being the Avellino eruption around 1800 BC which engulfed several Bronze Age settlements. Since AD 79, the volcano has also erupted repeatedly, in 172, 203, 222, possibly in 303, 379, 472, 512, 536, 685, 787, around 860, around 900, 968, 991, 999, 1006, 1037, 1049, around 1073, 1139, 1150, and there may have been eruptions in 1270, 1347, and 1500. The volcano erupted again in 1631, six times in the 18th century (including 1779 and 1794), eight times in the 19th century (notably in 1872), and in 1906, 1929 and 1944. There have been no eruptions since 1944, and none of the eruptions after AD 79 were as large or destructive as the Pompeian one. Vesuvius entered a new phase in December 1631, when a major eruption buried many villages under lava flows, killing around 3,000 people. Torrents of lahar were also created, adding to the devastation. Activity thereafter became almost continuous, with relatively severe eruptions occurring in 1660, 1682, 1694, 1698, 1707, 1737, 1760, 1767, 1779, 1794, 1822, 1834, 1839, 1850, 1855, 1861, 1868, 1872, 1906, 1926, 1929, and 1944.

Question about the article:
413.target: When did an eruption happen five years after the 1850 severe eruption but 21 years before that one?
413.rationale: Here's a question for the given article:\n\nQuestion: When did an eruption happen five years after the 1850 severe eruption but 21 years before that one?

On 2 January 1905, Port Arthur was lost; in February 1905, the Russian army was defeated at Mukden, losing almost 80,000 men. On 27-28 May 1905, the Russian Baltic Fleet was defeated at Tsushima. Witte was dispatched to make peace, negotiating the Treaty of Portsmouth . In 1905, there were naval mutinies at Sevastopol , Vladivostok, and Kronstadt, peaking in June with the mutiny aboard the battleship Potemkin. The mutineers eventually surrendered the battleship to Romanian authorities on 8 July in exchange for asylum, then the Romanians returned her to Imperial Russian authorities on the following day. Some sources claim over 2,000 sailors died in the suppression. The mutinies were disorganised and quickly crushed. Despite these mutinies, the armed forces were largely apolitical and remained mostly loyal, if dissatisfied — and were widely used by the government to control the 1905 unrest.

418.source:
With his health continuing to deteriorate, the Black Prince returned to England in January 1371, whereby now his father Edward III was elderly and also in poor health. The prince's illness was debilitating, and he died on 8 June 1376. Edward III died the following year on 21 June 1377; he was succeeded by the Black Prince's second son Richard II , who was still a child. The treaty at Brétigny left Edward III and England with enlarged holdings in France; however, a small professional French army under the leadership of du Guesclin pushed the English back and, by the time of Charles V's death in 1380, the English only held Calais and a few other coastal cities. It was usual to appoint a regent in the case of a child monarch, but no regent was appointed for Richard II, who nominally exercised the power of kingship from the date of his accession in 1377. However, between 1377 and 1380, actual power was in the hands of a series of councils. The political community preferred this to a regency led by the king's uncle, John of Gaunt, although Gaunt remained highly influential. Richard faced many challenges during his reign, including the Peasants' Revolt led by Wat Tyler in 1381 and an Anglo-Scottish war in 1384-1385. His attempts to raise taxes to pay for his Scottish adventure and for the protection of Calais against the French made him increasingly unpopular.

Answer this question based on the article: Who died first, Edward III or the Black Prince?
418.rationale:
The Black Prince died first, according to the article above. The date of his death was 8 June 1376; on the other hand, Edward III died a year later than that in 21 June 1377

420.source:
Chinese political philosophy dates back to the Spring and Autumn Period, specifically with Confucius in the 6th century BC. Chinese political philosophy was developed as a response to the social and political breakdown of the country characteristic of the Spring and Autumn Period and the Warring States period. The major philosophies during the period, Confucianism, Legalism, Mohism, Agrarianism and Taoism, each had a political aspect to their philosophical schools. Philosophers such as Confucius, Mencius, and Mozi, focused on political unity and political stability as the basis of their political philosophies. Confucianism advocated a hierarchical, meritocratic government based on empathy, loyalty, and interpersonal relationships. Legalism advocated a highly authoritarian government based on draconian punishments and laws. Mohism advocated a communal, decentralized government centered on frugality and ascetism. The Agrarians advocated a peasant utopian communalism and egalitarianism. Taoism advocated a proto-anarchism. Legalism was the dominant political philosophy of the Qin Dynasty, but was replaced by State Confucianism in the Han Dynasty. Prior to China's adoption of communism, State Confucianism remained the dominant political philosophy of China up to the 20th century.
Chinese political philosophy dates back to what century?
420.rationale:
The question is asking when did Chinese political philosophy began. The answer to this can be found in the first sentence of the context, where it says "Chinese political philosophy dates back to the Spring and Autumn Period."
Then we need to figure out what century was that period. According to Wikipedia: https://en-gb.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spring_and_Autumn_period 
"The Spring and Autumn period (simplified Chinese: 春秋时代; traditional Chinese: 春秋時代) was a historical period in China following the Zhou dynasty[1] and preceding the Warring States period.[2][3]" Then looking up those two periods on wikipedia gives their years as 770 BC - 476

421.source:
In this task you will break down a question into the basic steps required to answer it.
 A question decomposition is a numbered list of operations that must be performed to answer the original question. Imagine explaining your question to a friendly droid by listing each action it should take in order for the question to be answered. Each step in our decomposition should refer to either an entity (known or unknown), a propery of an entity or a query operation (count, group, union, etc.)
 Here are the list of step templates and their description:
 Select: A select step is used to return a set of objects. There are no references to previous steps in a select step. template: Return [attributes]
 Filter: A filter step is used to return results from a previous step to which a certain condition applies. template: Return [#step] [condition]
 Project: A project step should return certain attributes of the results of a previous step. template: Return [attributes] of [#step]
 Aggregate: An aggregate step returns an aggregator function applied on a step's result. template: Return the [aggregator] of [#step].
 Group: A group step is an aggregator applied on attributes. template: Return the [aggregator] of [#step] for each [attribute]
 Superlative: A superlative step is used to return the result with a highest/lowest attribute among other results. template: Return [#step1] [where] [#step2] [is] [highest / lowest]
 Comparative: A comparative step is used when we need to compare an attribute with a number to filter results. template: Return [#step1] [where] [#step2] [comparator] [number] 
 Union: A union step is used to return results of two steps together. template: Return [#step1] [or / ,] [#step2]
 Intersection: An intersection step returns the result that two steps have in common. template: Return [attribute] of both [#step1] and [#step2]
 Discard: A discard step returns result of a step and excludes result of another step from it. template: Return [#step1] besides [#step2]
 Sort: A sort returns result of another step in a specific order. template: Return [#step1] [ordered / sorted by] [#step2]
 Is true: An is true step checks a condition on another result and returns a true or false. template: Return [is / if] [condition]
 Arithmetic: An arithmatic step operates an arithmatic operation on one or more steps. template: Return the [arithmetic op.] of [#step1] [and] [#step2].

430.source:
In this task you are given a disfluent question, a proper question and a context. A disfluent question is a question that has some interruptions in it while framing and a proper question is the correct form of the question without any disfluency. Classify whether the question is answerable or not based on the given context.

proper question: What is one thing cilia don't have? 
 disfluent question: What is one thing cilia have, oh wait, they don't have? 
 context: The Beroida, also known as Nuda, have no feeding appendages, but their large pharynx, just inside the large mouth and filling most of the saclike body, bears macrocilia at the oral end. These fused bundles of several thousand large cilia are able to bite off pieces of prey that are too large to swallow whole – almost always other ctenophores. In front of the field of macrocilia, on the mouth lips in some species of Beroe, is a pair of narrow strips of adhesive epithelial cells on the stomach wall that zip the mouth shut when the animal is not feeding, by forming intercellular connections with the opposite adhesive strip. This tight closure streamlines the front of the animal when it is pursuing prey.
430.rationale: The correct answer to the question is "cilia" which has been already mentioned in context. Hence, it is not answerable from this particular context."

432.source:
In this task you will break down a question into the basic steps required to answer it.
 A question decomposition is a numbered list of operations that must be performed to answer the original question. Imagine explaining your question to a friendly droid by listing each action it should take in order for the question to be answered. Each step in our decomposition should refer to either an entity (known or unknown), a propery of an entity or a query operation (count, group, union, etc.)
 Here are the list of step templates and their description:
 Select: A select step is used to return a set of objects. There are no references to previous steps in a select step. template: Return [attributes]
 Filter: A filter step is used to return results from a previous step to which a certain condition applies. template: Return [#step] [condition]
 Project: A project step should return certain attributes of the results of a previous step. template: Return [attributes] of [#step]
 Aggregate: An aggregate step returns an aggregator function applied on a step's result. template: Return the [aggregator] of [#step].
 Group: A group step is an aggregator applied on attributes. template: Return the [aggregator] of [#step] for each [attribute]
 Superlative: A superlative step is used to return the result with a highest/lowest attribute among other results. template: Return [#step1] [where] [#step2] [is] [highest / lowest]
 Comparative: A comparative step is used when we need to compare an attribute with a number to filter results. template: Return [#step1] [where] [#step2] [comparator] [number] 
 Union: A union step is used to return results of two steps together. template: Return [#step1] [or / ,] [#step2]
 Intersection: An intersection step returns the result that two steps have in common. template: Return [attribute] of both [#step1] and [#step2]
 Discard: A discard step returns result of a step and excludes result of another step from it. template: Return [#step1] besides [#step2]
 Sort: A sort returns result of another step in a specific order. template: Return [#step1] [ordered / sorted by] [#step2]
 Is true: An is true step checks a condition on another result and returns a true or false. template: Return [is / if] [condition]
 Arithmetic: An arithmatic step operates an arithmatic operation on one or more steps. template: Return the [arithmetic op.] of [#step1] [and] [#step2].

question: Is the material of any of thre balls the same as the cube?
432.target: #1 return balls #2 return cube #3 return materials of #1 #4 return material of #2 #5 return #1 where #3 Is the same as #4 #6 return Is there  any  #5
432.rationale: The question asks whether the material of some or all balls is equal to that of the cube. To answer this, we firstly need a list of materials and then find which one matches with our query.<sep> Step #1: return balls<sep> Step #2: return cube <sep>Step #3; Return materials (a set) from step 1 i.e., Set_materials(balls).<sep>Step#4 :Return material (an attribute) form step 2 i.e., material(cube).<sep>Step#5 :Return ball(step1), where it's material=material(cube)(step 4), thus returning those balls whose attributes match.<sep> Is there any condition in 5 ? yes

434.source:
In this task, you have to generate the title of the recipe given its required ingredients and directions.

ingredients:  '10 large tomatoes', '10 large apples (unpeeled)', '2 green peppers', '2 red peppers', '4 onions', '1 bunch celery', '3 c. sugar', '1 Tbsp. salt', '1 Tbsp. mustard seed', '1 pt. vinegar',<sep> directions: 'Cut or chop fine tomatoes, apples, peppers, onions and celery, then add sugar, salt, mustard seed and vinegar.', 'Boil until quite thick (about 2 hours).', 'Ingredients can be ground, if desired.', 'Put in hot jars and seal.'
434.rationale: The recipe involves cutting up the ingredients, and then boiling them until quite thick. The final step of putting it in jars implies that this is a relish or pickle type food product. The title "Apple-Tomato Relish" seems appropriate given the list of ingredients, which includes apples and tomatoes as well as other common items found in relishes like peppers, onions, celery, sugar, vinegar etc.'

question: If there are exactly three towels in the right image.
435.target: #1 return right image #2 return towels in  #1 #3 return number of  #2 #4 return if  #3 is equal to  three
435.rationale:
The question can be decomposed into the following steps:

#1: Return right image. This step returns only the objects in one of the images (right). 
#2: Return towels in #1. Since we are looking for a specific type of object inside the results from Step 1, this is where we select it out to find what's important. 
#3: Return number of  #2 . The next step looks at how many towels were returned by Step 2 and counts them; then, that result is stored as 'number'.
#4 : return if  #3 is equal to   three. Finally, check whether or not there are exactly 3 towels using an "is true" template with a condition describing that relation."

question: If in the image to the right, some of the crab's legs are red.
437.target: #1 return right image #2 return crabs in  #1 #3 return legs of #2 #4 return #2 where  #3 are red #5 return number of  #4 #6 return if  #5 is at least one
437.rationale: The question is asking if some of the crab's legs are red. We first need to return a visual representation of what we're talking about, as well as select all crabs in that image. Then, we get the set of legs for each crab and filter down to only those with at least one leg on which there is any red color (the right-most example). Finally, we check whether this number is greater than 1 or not; i.e., did more than one crab have a single red leg?

452.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head includes an event or an action in the Tail or not. This happens when the Tail denotes a step within the larger head event. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX 'd better go<sep>Tail: Tardy
452.rationale: The phrase "PersonX 'd better go" is an action in and of itself. The word "Tardy", which means late, does not describe a step within that action.

453.source:

The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head causes the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: sex<sep>Tail: venereal disease
453.rationale: Since sex may lead to venereal disease, the Head causes Tail.

454.source:
In this task, you are presented with a term, a question, and a yes/no answer. For context, the term is associated with a short description. Write the simple facts one needs to know in order to answer the given question. The facts should be easily found on the web (e.g. mentioned in a Wikipedia page)

Term: Hyena, Description: family of mammal, Question: Can hyenas survive on steak alone?, Answer:Yes
454.target: Fact1: Hyenas are carnivores. Fact2: Carnivores survive by eating meat. Fact3: Steak is a form of meat.
454.rationale: The question asks whether hyenas can survive on steak alone. The term description tells us that they are a family of mammals, while the answer is yes which means that they can survive by eating only meat (i.e., steaks).\nTo decompose this question, we need to know what carnivores eat and if steak fits into their diet as such meals provide them with all necessary nutrients for survival. Thus our three facts would be:\n#1: Hyenas are carnivores; #2: Carnivores survive by eating meat; Fact3# Steak is a form of meat."

Generated sentences must be short, have fewer than 10 words, and be simple as if narrating to a child. Avoid using any irrelevant extra information when creating the ending, and use names instead of pronouns (e.g. he / she) wherever possible.

Beginning: It was game day and my friends and I were ready for our game. Middle: We beat the other team 30-10.

456.source:
In this task, you're given a context, a sentence,  and a character. The sentence describes an action or job of the given character. Also, the context provides more information about the sentence or the character. Your task is to return one of the emotions which are expressed by the Character in the given sentence. For that you can use the Context; however, Context is not provided in all the inputs. Also, in some inputs, there can be zero emotion; for that return 'None'.

Context: None 
 Sentence: Tim is part of the school soccer team. 
 Character: Soccer team
456.rationale: The sentence states that Tim is part of the school soccer team, but does not provide any information about how he feels. Since there is no context provided and we don't know much about Tim's personality or experiences with being on a soccer team, it makes sense to return "None" as the emotion expressed by him in this situation.

457.source:
In this task, you are given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY, or others, feel what is mentioned in the Tail or not. Feelings in this task are the emotional reactions on the part of PersonY or other participants in an event. For example, as a result of gift-giving, others (in this case, PersonY) might feel appreciated. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX joins the team<sep>Tail: happy
457.rationale: "Joining the team" might make PersonX, teammates and others (PersonY) feel happy.

460.source:
Given a premise, an initial context, an original ending, and a new ending, the task is to generate the counterfactual context that is aligned with the new ending. Each instance consists of a five-sentence story. The premise is the first sentence of a story, and the second sentence, which is the initial context, provides more information about the story's context. The original ending is the last three sentences of the story. Also, you are given a new ending that can provide the new story with the same premise. You should write a counterfactual context to explain the small differences between the original and new endings. More specifically, a story context contains the general plot of the story. And a counterfactual context is a slight modification to the initial context. To sum up, you should write the second sentence of a story based on the premise(first sentence) and the new ending(last three sentences) of the story.

Premise: Emma had some friends stay the night. 
 Initial Context: They were up all night telling ghost stories. 
 Original Ending: They all got scared. They cried and wanted to call their moms. Emma decided not to have sleepovers anymore. 
 New ending: They all got embarrassed. The mood got awkward, and they all wished they had never said anything. Emma decided not to have sleepovers anymore.
460.target: They were up all night telling stories about their crushes
460.rationale: The new ending describes the mood as awkward and explains that they all wish they had never said anything. This implies that instead of telling ghost stories, they were probably talking about their crushes or something else embarrassing. Therefore we can infer from this information that a suitable counterfactual context would be "They were up all night telling stories about their crushes".

461.source:
In this task, we ask you to write an event that is not likely to happen after a certain event or is not likely to have happened before it. Pay attention that you will be asked the correct question, and you need to answer it incorrectly. For example, "earning money" usually appears before "spending money". Even though there exist multiple wrong answers, we only need a single wrong answer. Please try to keep your "answer" as simple as possible. Concise and simple "answer" is preferred over those complex and verbose ones.

Sentence: At NEADS, the report of the hijacking was relayed immediately to Battle Commander Colonel Robert Marr. 
Question: What happened after the hijacking threat was reported?
461.rationale: The example is discussing the immediate response to a hijacking threat. There was no time for them (the military) do nothing in between receiving the report and responding.

Sentence 1: Allie wanted to go on a camping trip. Sentence 2: So she got her friends together to go. Sentence 3: But when they got there she got scared. Sentence 4: They saw a wolf. Sentence 5: Allie then wanted to go home.

463.source:
In this task, you're given the title of a five-sentence story and the first four sentences. Your job is to write the last sentence of the story to not connect with the rest of the story. Ensure that the generated sentence is contextually relevant to the story.

Title: Perfume. Sentence 1: Patrick came home from work and greeted his wife. Sentence 2: He gave her a kiss on the check and noticed something different. Sentence 3: An unfamiliar aroma reached his nose. Sentence 4: He asked his wife if she had a new perfume on.

464.source:

Sentence1: After a long day at school, Mandy was tired. Sentence2: She wanted to nap before her favorite show started. Sentence3: But, Mandy had to clean her room and do her homework. Sentence4: She finished just in time to watch the show.
464.target: But, Mandy fell asleep during the show
464.rationale: After completing her room, Mandy was tired and fell asleep during the show.

465.source:
In this task, you need to indicate the presence of temporal reasoning in the provided question. Questions that involve temporal reasoning/understanding contain one of the following five temporal phenomena: First: "event duration", is defined as the understanding of how long events last (e.g.,"brushing teeth" usually takes a few minutes). Second: "transient v. stationary" events, which are based on the understanding of whether an event will change over time or not (e.g., "being born in the U.S." is a stationary event since it will last forever; "being hungry" is a transient event since it lasts for a short period of time). Third: "event ordering" is the understanding of how events are usually ordered (e.g., "earning money" usually comes before "spending money"). Fourth: "absolute timepoint" of events which is the understanding of when events usually happen (e.g., "going to school" usually happens during the day, not at 2 A.M). The last category is "frequency" of events, which refers to how often events are repeated (e.g., "taking showers" typically occurs ~5 times a week, "going to Saturday market" usually happens every few weeks/months, etc.). Indicate with `Yes` if the question involves temporal reasoning. Indicate with `No`, otherwise.

Sentence: The dermis also contains hair follicles and two types of glands. 
Question: Does the functioning of dermis slow down with age?

466.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head includes an event or an action in the Tail or not. This happens when the Tail denotes a step within the larger head event. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: go public<sep>Tail: sending out press release
466.rationale: Sending out a press release is part of going public.

467.source:
In this task, based on a given sentence, we ask you to write a question that involves the ordering of events, i.e., the understanding of how events are usually ordered. For example, "earning money" usually appears before "spending money". Don't create questions which have explicit mentions of answers in the text. Instead, it has to be implied from what is given. In other words, we want you to use "instinct" or "common sense". Note that the written questions are not required to have a single correct answer.

Sentence: He tried to halt the Dayaks' piracy and head-hunting while defending their more "morally acceptable" customs.
467.rationale: We want to know what happened after the protagonist tried to halt piracy and head-hunting.

468.source:
In this task, you are given a premise and hypothesis. The task is to classify them into three categories: 'positive' if the hypothesis supports the premise, 'negated' if it opposes the premise, and 'neutral' if it neither supports nor opposes it.

Premise : 'All ten ladies that discover those doors don't judge Nina to mess up a rug.','Hypothesis : There aren't exactly ten ladies that discover those doors.'
468.rationale: The premise states that all ten ladies do not judge Nina, whereas the hypothesis says there aren't exactly 10 of them. The hypothesis contradicts with some part of the premise and is therefore opposed to it.

469.source:
In this task you need to give reasons to justify the pronoun coreference relations. Each of the provided inputs contains a sentence with a target pronoun and a question about how to justify the coreference between a noun phrase and the target pronoun. Good practices involve the discussion about how the descriptions attached to the targeted pronoun relate to the noun phrase candidate in the question. The reasoning could come from one or multiple following knowledge types about commonsense: First: 'Property', the knowledge about property of objects (e.g., ice is cold). Second: 'Object', the knowledge about objects (e.g., cats have ears). Third: 'Eventuality', the knowledge about eventuality (e.g., 'wake up' happens before 'open eyes'). Forth: 'Spatial', the knowledge about spatial position (e.g., object at the back can be blocked). Fifth: 'Quantity', the knowledge about numbers (e.g., 2 is smaller than 10). Sixth: all other knowledge if above ones are not suitable. Write the sentence in natural language.

Sentence: Tom threw his schoolbag down to Ray after he reached the top of the stairs.
 Question: Why does the 'he' refer to tom?
469.target: Because Tom threw his bag down, so he would be at the top of the stairs
469.rationale: The pronoun 'he' is used to refer back to the subject in a sentence. In this case, Tom threw his bag down and would be at the top of stairs.

470.source:
Given a sentence with a missing word, pick the answer option that best fills out the missing word in the sentence. Indicate each answer with its index ('a', 'b', 'c', 'd').

Time is ____ less a dimension of our universe than is length, width, and height.\Question: Choose the right answer from options given a) nine b) five c) no d) seven
470.rationale: Time is a dimension like length, width and height. Therefore the answer should be "no"

471.source:
You are given a paragraph (Passage), a question (Question) and two answer options (Option1 and Option2). Your task is to choose the correct answer to the question based on the passage. Answer of the question cannot be found directly from the passage, it is indirectly indicated in the passage. Do not answer with words other than the two options, and do not answer with option titles(e.g. "option1" or "1" are not acceptable answers.)

Passage: Today my best friend is coming from out of town and I spent the entire weekend cleaning up my flat . I must have had 3 sink fulls of dishes to wash ! I made sure I took out all the trash , went back inside , and proceeded to vacuum my entire house . I made sure the bed was made in my guest room , and that there was clean sheets and towels for my friend . It was a good thing I did because it was a total mess . The last thing I had left to do was two weeks worth of laundry . While I was working on that I decided to get out my recipe for French apple pie and make a homemade pie since I had some yummy vanilla ice cream to go with it . I hope that I have some energy left by the time my friend gets here ! Question: What did they finish up while it was baking? Option1: washing dishes Option2: laundry
471.rationale: The passage describes the protagonist spending all weekend cleaning their house, so they will have some clean clothes to wear. This implies that they most likely finished up laundry after making the pie.

472.source:
In this task, you are given a sentence with a missing word that can be an object, a person, and/or an action. Fill in the blank with a plausible word. Although each sentence has many correct answers, you only have to write one answer.

PersonX pays ___ to the fact
472.rationale: A person who pays marbles to a fact is not paying attention and is distracted by something else.

473.source:
In this task you are given a story and a question regarding that story. You must judge whether the question is answerable based on the info given to you. Label the instances as "Answerable" or "Not Answerable" based on your judgment. the story and the question are separated by a new line character.

Tory believed that one day her cat would come home. She waited by the window often for her companion. One day there was a knock at the door. It was a man carrying her cat. She was crying with happiness.
Why did Tory believe that one day her cat would come home?
473.rationale: The story does not tell us why Tory believed that her cat would come home.

474.source:
Two analogies that relate items to whether they are trash or treasure is given in the form "A : B. C : ?". Items marked as "trash" are considered to not have value and can be disposed, whereas those marked as "treasure" are considered valuable items that must be retained. "A : "B relates item A to whether it is trash or treasure, as specified by B. Your task is to replace the question mark (?) with either `trash` or `treasure` for the given item C, following the "A : B" relation.

crumbs : trash. mud : ?
474.rationale: Both crumbs and mud are considered "trash" as they have no value.

475.source:
Given a sentence, generate a most likely context or previous statement. The previous statement should be relevant to the given statement.

More people are then seen riding down a hill in rafts for the mountain while the people continue to go down the slopes.
475.target: Many people are seen riding skis and snowboards as well as up lifts to the top of the mountain
475.rationale: The previous statement provides context that the mountain is a ski resort and people are riding up lifts to go skiing.

476.source:
You are provided with an "Event", "Intent" and "XEmotion" (PersonX's reactions for the given "Event"). Indicate PersonY's reaction (person feels) at the end of this event. Provide one reaction for PersonY. If there's nothing that can be implied, respond as None

Event:PersonX crosses my heart and hope to die. Intent: 1) to spread on his toast. XEmotion: 1) proud about his skills
476.rationale: A person who crosses their heart and hope to die is expressing an oath with the intent of spreading it on his toast. The fact that he does this indicates a sense of pride about his skills, which implicates trust for someone else. Therefore, PersonY most likely feels trusting toward PersonX."

477.source:
You are given a question and some answer options (associated with "A", "B", "C", "D"). You should choose the correct answer based on commonsense knowledge. Avoid answering questions based on associations, the set of answers are chosen deliberately to capture common sense beyond associations. Do not generate anything else apart from one of the following characters: 'A', 'B, 'C', 'D', 'E' and only give one answer for each question.

A human wants to submerge himself in water, what should he use?
(A)whirlpool bath (B)coffee cup (C)cup (D)soft drink (E)puddle
477.rationale: The human would most likely use a whirlpool bath to submerge himself in water.

478.source:
In this task, you will be given a short story. One sentence from the story is chosen. Consider the events that happen before that sentence, or are likely to have happened before it. Does any of them directly cause it, or simply make it possible? You should write your answer in the form " A >causes/enables> B". Try to use phrases and sentences from the story to compose your answer when possible.

story: Juan was having a terrible day at work. Customers were complaining about the lack of open registers. But there was nothing he could do about it. During break time, Juan yelled at his boss. He was immediately fired.
 selected sentence: Juan was having a terrible day at work.
478.target: Customers complain a lot >Causes/Enables> Juan has a bad day at work
478.rationale: The customers' complaints directly cause Juan to have a terrible day at work.

479.source:
Given a sentence, generate a most unlikely next statement. The next statement should not be logically relevant to the given context

Someone stares at his son as he shoves pills into a banana. Someone
479.rationale: The given sentence does not have any context to infer what happens next. The answer could be anything that is most unlikely happening after the event in the given sentence

480.source:
In this task, we ask you to write an implausible answer to a question that involves "transient v. stationary" events, i.e., the understanding of whether an event will change over time or not. For example, the sentence "he was born in the U.S." contains a stationary event since it will last forever; however, "he is hungry" contains a transient event since it will remain true for a short period of time. Even though there exist multiple wrong answers, we only need a single wrong answer. Please try to keep your "answer" as simple as possible. Concise and simple "answer" is preferred over those complex and verbose ones.

Sentence: Most of us have seen steam rising off a wet road after a summer rainstorm. 
Question: Was the road wet the next sunny day?
480.rationale: The sentence states that a road was wet after a summer rainstorm. This is a transient event since the road will dry up in time due to environmental factors such as evaporation and heat from sunlight, but it does not state how much longer the water would last on the road. The question asks if the same portion of this particular road still had remnants of water left over from yesterday's rainstorm. Since there are no additional facts indicating otherwise, we can assume that enough moisture remains for us to acknowledge yes, the part of our chosen street/road is still wet even though it isn't raining anymore today; however, an implausible answer could be "yes" since without any further information about whether or not there remained standing puddles on this specific route (or perhaps other variables like

481.source:
You are given a paragraph (Passage), a question (Question) and two answer options (Option1 and Option2). Your task is to choose the correct answer to the question based on the passage. Answer of the question cannot be found directly from the passage, it is indirectly indicated in the passage. Do not answer with words other than the two options, and do not answer with option titles(e.g. "option1" or "1" are not acceptable answers.)

Passage: Omelettes make a great breakfast , and I enjoy making them because they are very easy to cook . First , I get the eggs out and begin cracking them on the side of the bowl and dumping them into the bowl . I normally use two eggs whites and one whole egg to cut the calories . I add some salt and pepper to the mix for flavor . I pour the mixture into the hot frying pan . I make sure that I add some vegetable oil to the pan before I add the eggs though because I do n't want them to stick . As this occurs , I add some cheese or vegetable to the center of the egg mixture . Really , almost any type of cheese or vegetable makes a good omelette . I then flip one side of the omelette over on to itself to seal in the contents in the middle . It is then ready to serve ! Question: When is it lightly brown on both sides? Option1: when it's done Option2: when it's not done
481.rationale: The passage describes the process of making an omelette and states that "I add some vegetable oil to the pan before I add the eggs though because I don't want them to stick." Since one doesn't want their eggs to stick, it is important not to cook them too long. This suggests that we should choose option1 since this would make sense with light browning on both sides (not much time has passed).

482.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head happens after the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX accidentally shot<sep>Tail: to stop the bleeding
482.rationale: The head indicates that PersonX accidentally shot something or someone, while the tail implies that they did so to stop bleeding. Therefore, it appears as though the head event happened before the tail one in order for them to attempt stopping any blood loss afterwards.

483.source:
Given a sentence, fill out the missing word with a 'no' or a number (between zero and ten). You should write the numbers with english alphabet, like: four instead of 4.

Bacteria produce ____ diffrent ways, sexually and asexually.
483.rationale: The sentence is asking about reproduction by bacteria. It points out that there are two ways for this to happen: sexually and asexually.

484.source:
In this task, you are given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY, or others, feel what is mentioned in the Tail or not. Feelings in this task are the emotional reactions on the part of PersonY or other participants in an event. For example, as a result of gift-giving, others (in this case, PersonY) might feel appreciated. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX holds another ___<sep>Tail: none
484.rationale: PersonX's action of holding another object can be interpreted as a sign that they want to avoid emotional connection with others.

485.source:
Given a story, answer the question about the story. The question is the last sentence in the input. These stories can be difficult due to their length and how each story has at least one of the three following scenarios: the first is when the individual's belief matches reality, the second is when the individual's belief does not match reality, and the third is when an individual has a false belief about another individual's beliefs. The question will ask about the location of an object in the story with respect to either none or one of the three scenarios. Note that there are distractor sentences in each story that are unrelated to the question and are designed to confuse the reader.

Aiden entered the front_yard. Phone rang. Jayden entered the front_yard. The pear is in the red_pantry. Jayden exited the front_yard. Aiden moved the pear to the blue_box. Aiden entered the laundry. Jayden entered the laundry. The banana is in the green_bottle. Jayden exited the laundry. Aiden moved the banana to the green_box. Aiden is in the laundry. James entered the laundry. The banana is in the green_box. James exited the laundry. Aiden moved the banana to the green_bottle. Aiden entered the front_yard. James entered the front_yard. The pear is in the blue_box. Phone rang. James exited the front_yard. Aiden moved the pear to the red_pantry. Where is the pear really?
485.rationale: James never moved the pear, and Aiden was responsible for all of its movements. This story is an example of when a character's belief matches reality.

486.source:
In this task, you will be given a passage consisting of set of facts. The task is to create a question of form 'Where is <person_name>?' that is answerable from exactly one of the given facts. Avoid creating questions that are unanswerable from all of the facts.

Passage: Mary moved to the kitchen. Sandra moved to the kitchen. Mary went to the garden. John moved to the bedroom. Mary journeyed to the office. Mary went to the bathroom. Sandra travelled to the garden. Daniel went back to the hallway.
486.rationale: This question can be answered by the fact: "John moved to the bedroom."

487.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail or not. Being characterized usually describes entities' general characteristics such as rose is red, or subjective attributes such as thirst is uncomfortable. It can also map to descriptors that speak to the substance or value of items such as meat has the property of being stored in the freezer or bike is powered by a person's legs. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: stage<sep>Tail: elevated above surrounding ground area
487.rationale: The Head, stage, is characterized by being elevated above the surrounding ground area.

488.source:
Given a pair of words, deduce the type of relationship between them. The various types of relations are: 'HYPER', 'COORD' and 'RANDOM'. Let's denote the first word by X and the second word by Y. A COORD relationship holds when X and Y belong to the same semantic class. A HYPER relationship applies when X is a specific instance of Y. If niether COORD nor HYPER are applicable then the relationship is RANDOM.

X: bottle, Y: artifact
488.rationale: A bottle is a specific instance of an artifact.

489.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head happens after the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX acts funny<sep>Tail: staisfied
489.rationale: The Head event is acting funny and the Tail event is satisfied. Based on this prompt, it seems that PersonX has already been satisfied prior to them acting funny; therefore, we can conclude that being satisfied does not follow by a person's action of acting funny.

490.source:
Two analogies that relate items to whether they are trash or treasure is given in the form "A : B. C : ?". Items marked as "trash" are considered to not have value and can be disposed, whereas those marked as "treasure" are considered valuable items that must be retained. "A : "B relates item A to whether it is trash or treasure, as specified by B. Your task is to replace the question mark (?) with either `trash` or `treasure` for the given item C, following the "A : B" relation.

rind : trash. baby : ?
490.rationale: The rind of a fruit is considered trash and does not have value. Therefore, it can be disposed. A baby on the other hand, has great value to its parents or caregivers as they are precious lives entrusted in their care.

491.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail or not. Being characterized usually describes entities' general characteristics such as rose is red, or subjective attributes such as thirst is uncomfortable. It can also map to descriptors that speak to the substance or value of items such as meat has the property of being stored in the freezer or bike is powered by a person's legs. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: castanets<sep>Tail: lightweight
491.rationale: Castanets are lightweight instruments that can be held and played in the hands.

492.source:
In this task, you're given a story (which contains five sentences only). Your task is to find all the characters which are available in the given story.

Sentence1: Michael and Luke are roommates. Sentence2: Luke is very messy. Sentence3: Michael got very upset with Luke's mess one day. Sentence4: Michael told Luke to move out. Sentence5: He needs a new roommate now.
492.rationale: The story is about two roommates, Michael and Luke. Michael became upset with the mess that his roommate, Luke created one day.

493.source:
In this task, you are given a tuple, comprising Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether, as a result of the Head, PersonY or others will want what is mentioned in the Tail or not. In this task, wanting is a postcondition desire on the part of PersonY and others, respectively. For example, as a result of PersonX giving PersonY gifts, PersonY may want to open the gift. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX goes on PersonY's way<sep>Tail: to yell at PersonX
493.rationale: PersonX going on PersonY's way could result in PersonY wanting to yell at them.

494.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head happens before the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX acts in PersonY manner<sep>Tail: foolish
494.rationale: PersonX acts in PersonY manner (Head) is a general statement that does not specify any time. Therefore, it could happen before or after the Tail event of "foolish", which means the Head and Tail events are independent from each other.

495.source:
In this task, you will be presented with a question having multiple possible answers in Russian language. And you should choose a most suitable option out of "A", "B", "C", "D", and "E" based on your commonsense knowledge.

Question: Где люди хранят свои банки с едой? 
 Options: A супермаркет B центр утилизации C рюкзак D дом E холодильник
495.rationale: Дом (D) - это основная привычка, удобное или самое легкое место.

496.source:
In this task, you are given an impractical statement. You are also given three reasons (associated with "A", "B", "C") explaining why this statement doesn't make sense. You must choose the most corresponding reason explaining why this statement doesn't make sense.

Cars cause nothing to the environment.
(A) Cars can go very fast.
(B)Cars are good for travelling long distances.
(C)Cars emit carbon dioxide which causes climate change. Causing more frequent natural disasters.
496.rationale: Although A and B are true, C is the most corresponding reason explaining why this statement doesn't make sense.

497.source:
Formulate questions about the information mentioned in a given passage.

context: A person is trying to stack flowers, eggs, books, and balls.
497.target: What are the things that the person is trying to stack?
497.rationale: The question is a general one that can be answered by the information given in the context.

498.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head can be characterized by being or having the Tail or not. Being characterized usually describes entities' general characteristics such as rose is red, or subjective attributes such as thirst is uncomfortable. It can also map to descriptors that speak to the substance or value of items such as meat has the property of being stored in the freezer or bike is powered by a person's legs. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX asks PersonY to make<sep>Tail: to make more
498.rationale: PersonX has been characterized by asking PersonY for something, but not specifically to make more.

499.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head includes an event or an action in the Tail or not. This happens when the Tail denotes a step within the larger head event. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: compete<sep>Tail: ready emotionally and physically
499.rationale: Being ready emotionally and physically is an action that must be done before competing.

500.source:
In this task, we ask you to write an implausible answer to a question that involves "transient v. stationary" events, i.e., the understanding of whether an event will change over time or not. For example, the sentence "he was born in the U.S." contains a stationary event since it will last forever; however, "he is hungry" contains a transient event since it will remain true for a short period of time. Even though there exist multiple wrong answers, we only need a single wrong answer. Please try to keep your "answer" as simple as possible. Concise and simple "answer" is preferred over those complex and verbose ones.

Sentence: Wallace lives in Athens, W. Va., with her husband Rob, 37, and her daughters Rachel, 11, and Claire, 5. 
Question: Is Wallace still married?
500.rationale: The sentence is discussing Wallace's current life. However, the question asks whether she is still married or not which implies that her marriage might be over at some point in time.

501.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head happens after the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX acts funny<sep>Tail: to feel better
501.rationale: In the context of this question, acting funny is an action that PersonX takes to make themselves feel better. Therefore, it occurs before feeling better and not after.

502.source:
Construct a question that every answer in the list is correct and reasonable for it.

harry potter, bible, chronicals of narnia, willy wonka, lord of the rings, catcher in the rye
502.target: name a book you'd like to get as a gift
502.rationale: Each item in the list is a book that you can give as a gift.

503.source:
Given a math word problem, answer the following question. You might need to apply addition or subtraction mathematical operators on the numbers embedded in the text to answer the question and then only report the final numerical answer.

adam put 18 items in the shopping cart . after deleting some he had 8 left . how many items did adam delete ?
503.rationale: Adam puts 18 items in the shopping cart, then he deletes some and has 8 left. So we can conclude that Adam deleted 10 items by subtracting "8" from "18".

504.source:
In this task, you will be given two sentences separated by ", so". You should decide whether the first sentence can be the cause of the second sentence. If you can see a possible causation, answer with "plausible", otherwise answer with "not plausible".

The woman upgraded her computer hardware, so I gave it a shot
504.rationale: The woman upgrading her computer hardware can cause the narrator to give something a shot. For example, if she upgraded it because of some new software that was released and the narrator decided he wanted to try out this new software as well.

505.source:
In this task, you will be shown a short story with a beginning, two potential middles, and an ending. Your job is to choose the middle statement that makes the story incoherent / implausible by indicating 1 or 2 in the output. If both sentences are plausible, pick the one that makes less sense.

Beginning: Rebecca has to give her first speech in public speaking class. Middle 1: She was very nervous. Middle 2: She was very excited. Ending: She settled into a groove, and ended up loving the task.
505.rationale: Middle 1 indicates that Rebecca was nervous because giving her first speech in public speaking class is a challenging task. Middle 2 also indicates that she feels excited to give the speech, but doesn't explain why. So Middle 2 makes less sense.

506.source:
A question that is free of any grammatical or logcal errors, should be labeled 'yes', otherwise it should be indicated as 'no'. A question is grammatically correct if all its entities i.e. nouns, verbs, adjectives, prepositions, pronouns, adverbs are at appropriate position. A question is logically correct if the semantic makes sense.

Sentence: In this case he looks to his girlfriend , Violet . 
Question: Is he still looking at Violet now?
506.rationale: The sentence indicates that he is still looking at Violet.

507.source:
In this task, you will be presented with a question that has multiple possible answers. You should choose the most suitable option out of "A", "B", "C", "D", and "E", based on your commonsense knowledge.

Question: Where might a vacuum be stored? 
 Options: A space B container C orbit D dyson E closet
507.rationale: A vacuum is an object that a person would use at home, so it should be stored where the user can easily reach. Among the options provided, only closet seems suitable for this purpose.

508.source:
In this task, you will be presented with a question that has multiple possible answers. You should choose the most suitable option out of "A", "B", "C", "D", and "E", based on your commonsense knowledge.

Question: Outside of the city where could you find a sloth in a small zoo? 
 Options: A cage B encyclopedia C wilderness D dictionary E countryside
508.rationale: A sloth is a type of animal that would not be enclosed in a cage, so "A" is incorrect. To find information about an animal such as the sloth, you would want to look through resources like encyclopedias and dictionaries - these are not places where you could find one physically located or living. So options B and D can also be eliminated. Based on what we know (that they live in tropical forests), it makes sense that they might appear in the countryside outside of cities which have small zoos.

509.source:
Given a math word problem, answer the following question. You might need to apply addition or subtraction mathematical operators on the numbers embedded in the text to answer the question and then only report the final numerical answer.

adam picked 35 strawberries . after eating some he had 33 left . how many strawberries did adam eat ?
509.rationale: Adam started with 35 strawberries, and after eating some he had 33 left. By subtracting 33 from 35 (35-33=2), we can determine that Adam ate 2 strawberries.

510.source:
Given a phrase describing the relationship between two words, extract the words and the lexical relationship between them. The relation has to be of the type 'MemberOf', 'MadeOf', 'Synonym', 'Entails', 'HasA', 'HasProperty', 'PartOf', 'Antonym' or 'IsA'. The output should have the format: word1 relation word2.

game can be used with the same meaning of play
510.rationale: The phrase states that "game" and "play" are synonyms.

511.source:
In this task, you will be presented with a question that has multiple possible answers. You should choose the most suitable option out of "A", "B", "C", "D", and "E", based on your commonsense knowledge.

Question: A disposable razor is aptly named, it ends up where? 
 Options: A supermarket B hotel room C garbage D closet E medicine cabinet
511.rationale: A disposable razor is meant to be thrown out after a certain number of uses.

512.source:
In this task, you are given a short passage that conveys stereotype or anti-stereotype about a specific target. A stereotype is an over-generalized belief about a particular group of people. An anti-stereotype is an idea that goes against a common stereotype. You are expected to classify the passage into four types of stereotype or anti-stereotype: gender, profession, race, and religion.

Passage: Syria is a country filled with peace.
512.rationale: The passage is describing a generalization about the people of Syria, which falls under race.

513.source:
Given a prompt and four completions, select the completion that is the most plausible in continuing or answering the prompt. This task is designed to test common sense and has various categories ranging between idioms, negated statements, polysemy, subject referencing, and quantitative reasoning. Generate either Completion A, Completion B, Completion C, or Completion D.

Prompt: I really had to go to the bathroom. I 
Completion A: had to watch a bathroom etiquette tutorial to understand why. 
Completion B: stole the feces from the cat. 
Completion C: briefly sent the emoji to him. 
Completion D: quickly located the key to the washroom.
513.rationale: The prompt states the narrator is in need of a washroom and they quickly locate the key. This implies that they are able to find what they were looking for which would be completion D, so this option makes more sense within context compared to A, B & C

514.source:
Given a story, answer the question about the story. The question is the last sentence in the input. These stories can be difficult due to their length and how each story has at least one of the three following scenarios: the first is when the individual's belief matches reality, the second is when the individual's belief does not match reality, and the third is when an individual has a false belief about another individual's beliefs. The question will ask about the location of an object in the story with respect to either none or one of the three scenarios. Note that there are distractor sentences in each story that are unrelated to the question and are designed to confuse the reader.

Mason entered the kitchen. Liam entered the kitchen. The watermelon is in the red_cupboard. Mason moved the watermelon to the blue_treasure_chest. Liam entered the crawlspace. Mia entered the crawlspace. The potato is in the green_basket. Liam moved the potato to the red_pantry. Mason entered the sunroom. Avery entered the sunroom. The spinach is in the red_crate. Mason moved the spinach to the green_suitcase. Avery entered the kitchen. Liam entered the kitchen. The watermelon is in the blue_treasure_chest. Avery moved the watermelon to the red_cupboard. Where is the watermelon really?
514.rationale: The watermelon was originally in the red_cupboard, which is consistent with both Mason's beliefs and reality. Liam moved the watermelon to a different location (the blue_treasure_chest), however Avery returned it back to its original position of being inside the red cupboard.

515.source:
In this task, you are given two phrases: Head and Tail, separated with <sep>. The Head and the Tail events are short phrases possibly involving participants. The names of specific people have been replaced by generic words (e.g., PersonX, PersonY, PersonZ). PersonX is always the subject of the event. You have to determine whether the Head causes the Tail or not. Classify your answers into "Yes" and "No". The phrase may also contain "___", a placeholder that can be an object, a person, and/or an action.

Head: PersonX accepts happily<sep>Tail: thankful
515.rationale: PersonX being "thankful" does not imply that PersonX accepted something. Therefore, the Head does not cause Tail to happen in this case.

516.source:
You are given a target race, and two sentences. Your task is to determine whether the second sentence is either a stereotype, anti-stereotype, or is unrelated with respect to the first sentence and the target. A stereotype is a widely held but oversimplified notion of a group of people. An anti-stereotype is an idea that goes against the widely held but oversimplified notion of a group of people. Sentences and targets are unrelated if there is no relevance between them.

Target: Jordan 
Jordan is an Arab kingdom in Western Asia. Mint chocolate chip is the best.
516.rationale: In this example, the first sentence provides a description of Jordan as an Arab kingdom. The second sentence is about mint chocolate chip being the best flavor. There is no relevance between these two sentences and therefore they are unrelated to each other in relation to the target "Jordan".

517.source:
In this task, based on the given input, we ask you to write a question about when an event happened. Your question should be answerable with common knowledge on when events usually take place. For example, "going to school" usually happens during the day (not at 2 A.M). Don't create questions which have explicit mentions of answers in the text. Instead, it has to be implied from what is given. In other words, we want you to use "instinct" or "common sense". The written questions are not required to have a single correct answer.

Sentence: Police Captain Richard Brookwell calls Cross and his partner , Tommy Kane , to the crime scene .
517.target: What time did they go to the crime scene?
517.rationale: The crime scene is the main event in this question, and it usually takes place during the day. We can deduct that Cross and his partner were called to the crime scene around daytime from common knowledge of when crimes take place.

518.source:
In this task, you will be shown a short story with a beginning, two potential middles, and an ending. Your job is to choose the middle statement that makes the story coherent / plausible by writing "1" or "2" in the output. If both sentences are plausible, pick the one that makes most sense.

Beginning: Last week I decided to get a new haircut. Middle 1: I couldn't find an appointment anywhere. Middle 2: I scheduled an appointment for cheap. Ending: I decided to just shave my head instead.
518.rationale: The beginning of the story is about a person who decides to get a new haircut. Middle 1 describes their experience trying to find an appointment for this purpose, which makes sense as it relates directly back to the beginning. On the other hand, middle 2 jumps into describing that they scheduled an appointment without any mention or connection from what was happening in middle 1 (not being able to find one anywhere). Therefore, we can conclude that middle 1 provides more cohesion and coherence with respect to the rest of the passage.

519.source:
In the following task, you are given a yes/no question, its answer, and additional information which includes a description of a key term in the question and several facts. Your task is to "decompose the question"i.e. write the steps required to construct the given answer where each step is a question that can be answered using Wikipedia articles. To decompose the question, think of a decomposition strategy you could apply to answer the question through a search against Wikipedia. The decomposition strategy might not be obvious for some questions. For this reason, you are provided with additional information. You are not required to write decompositions that exactly match the provided facts, they are only meant as guidance. If the facts are too noisy, think about how you would have used Wikipedia to answer this question to create the decomposition. "not_definitive_answer" is true if there is no clear answer i.e. the question is ambiguous or a subjective opinion."incorrect_answer" is true if the answer to the question is not correct. If the answer is incorrect, write a decomposition that evaluates the correct answer. Each question should be easy to answer based on simple facts from Wikipedia pages, or a simple check using the answers to preceding questions. To ensure this, we also ask you to enter a potential Wikipedia article that would contain the answer to each question. If you can not think of a Wikipedia page that can answer your question, please think of a different strategy. You do not need to enter a Wikipedia page for steps that don't add new information and only contain simple checks. The answer to the final question is the same as the answer to the original question. Every question's answer has an impact on the final answer and there should be no redundant steps in the decomposition.

Question: Does James Watson believe that Africans are inferior to Europeans?, Answer:Yes, Description of James Watson: American molecular biologist, geneticist, and zoologist, Fact1: James Watson is a geneticist, who believes in his own work., Fact2: James Watson is quoted as saying that genetic testing "proves" that Africans aren't as smart.
519.target: Step1: What profession is James Watson in? `, Step2: As #1, what was James quoted with saying about African Americans?, Step3: Did James Watson believe in his own work about #2?, Wikipedia page for step 1: James Watson, Wikipedia page for step 2: James Watson, Wikipedia page for step 3: James Watson, not_definitive_answer: False, incorrect_answer: False
519.rationale:
The question is asking if James Watson believes that Africans are inferior to Europeans. The description of James Watson tells us he is an American molecular biologist, geneticist, and zoologist.
To decompose the question, we can check what profession James Watson was in (Step1), which would lead us to his Wikipedia page. We also see from Fact 1 that "James Watson is a geneticist who believes in his own work." Next, by checking what exactly James said about African Americans (Step2) on this wiki page or elsewhere(Fact 2), we find out that: “That there are many people of color who are very talented, but don’t promote themselves as well as white people.."[...]"There’s a difference on the average between blacks and whites

520.source:
In this task, we ask you to write an answer to a question about when an event happened. For example, "going to school" usually happens during the day (not at 2 A.M). Note that a lot of the questions could have more than one correct answer. We only need a single most-likely answer. Please try to keep your "answer" as simple as possible. Concise and simple "answer" is preferred over those complex and verbose ones.

Sentence: After several years of private practice from 1982-90, he became the judge of Decatur County Court for a year. 
Question: When did he get a law degree?
520.rationale: In the given sentence, we can infer that he became a judge after leaving private practice for one year. To answer this question about when he got his law degree, it is helpful to understand what "private practice" means: it refers to someone who works as an independent lawyer without being employed by another person or organization. We are also told in the beginning of the sentence that before 1982 (the start date), he had been practicing privately from 1980-1982. So if you subtract 1 year from 1982 and then add 2 years back onto 1981, you get 1981 -- which was probably how long ago he earned his law degree.

521.source:
In this task, you're given the title and three arbitrary sentences out of a five-sentence story. You are also given three additional sentence options, a, b, and c, that may or may not belong to the story. Your job is to pick the two options that seamlessly connect with the rest of the story and their positions in the sentence order of the story; note that the selected choices may fit into the story at any point. Your answer must be in the form of '2a, 5b', where '2a' means the candidate sentence 'a' will be inserted as the 2nd sentence in the story. The answer must also be in the order of the selected choices, i.e., '2a, 5b' is allowed, and '5b, 2a' is not allowed. If options are equally plausible, pick the ones that make more sense.

Title: When she got her test back she passed with flying colors. Ann couldn't believe it and was thrilled. Her boyfriend then threw her a party afterwards. Choices: a.
