Since both \"parents\" and \"nests\" are essential for understanding this initial clause, these words should be included as a span from \"parents\" to \"build\", with additional key words at beginning/end such as "young", "robins"/"birds". The second part gives further details on why it is significant that young birds tend to construct similar-looking nests - namely because their parents constructed them before aka they have not seen them do so. So including keywords like \"(A

929.source:
You are given two sentences. You have to find if there is entailment or agreement of the Hypothesis by the Premise. From the given pair of sentences, you should identify if there is enough information in the Premise to support the claim made in the Hypothesis. The Premise may not exactly be the same as Hypothesis. Your task is to return 'entails' if the premise supports hypothesis else return 'neutral'.

Premise: Active transport requires the cell to spend energy, usually in the form of ATP . 
 Hypothesis: All cells need energy for processes like active transport.
929.rationale: The premise states that active transport requires a cell to spend energy, and the hypothesis claims that all cells need energy for processes like active transport. The premise provides evidence that supports this claim by stating one example of how cells use energy in order to perform different tasks. Therefore, it can be inferred from the premise that all cells require some type of energy source such as ATP in order to support certain biological functions or activities. As a result, Statement 2 entails or implies Statement 1.

A normal human cell has 46 chromosomes.
930.target: There are 46 chromosomes chromosomes in a diploid human cell
930.rationale: There are 46 chromosomes in a diploid human cell. A normal human cell has two copies of every chromosome, or is "diploid", so it contains double the number of chromosomes found in haploid cells, which only have one copy each.

931.source:
Given an abstract, generate a keyword (a noun phrase) that best describes the focus or contribution of the paper. Such keywords can be directly from the given abstract or outside it.

Abstract: Protein S deficiency is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait. Heterozygotes with a reduction of 50% in the plasma protein S concentration are at risk for the development of venous thromboembolism, often occurring at an early age without an apparent cause. In the majority of the patients thrombosis is restricted to the superficial or deep venous system of the legs. In this case report we describe the presence of mesenteric vein thrombosis in a 30-yr-old man with hereditary protein S deficiency. In his family protein S deficiency was also recognized in his mother, brother, and niece. Both his mother and brother had a history of thrombotic disease.
931.rationale: The abstract describes a case of protein S deficiency in a 30-year old patient, who had suffered from mesenteric vein thrombosis. Protein S deficiency is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and the patient's family members also exhibited this disease. The keyword "Adult" best captures the focus of the paper (on human patients) and summarizes its contribution to our understanding of hereditary diseases such as protein S deficiency."

933.source:

Your task is to classify whether the given category is correct or not by providing "True" and "False", respectively. Here are the definitions for the categories: Background (Why is this problem important? What relevant works have been created before? What is still missing in the previous works? What are the high-level research questions? How might this help other research or researchers?), Purpose (What specific things do the researchers want to do? What specific knowledge do the researchers want to gain? What specific hypothesis do the researchers want to test?), Method (How did the researchers do the work or find what they sought? What are the procedures and steps of the research?), or Finding (What did the researchers find out? Did the proposed methods work? Did the thing behave as the researchers expected?). ",

 Section: background

This is important because it highlights the usefulness and potential applications of using next-generation sequencing (NGS)-based methods for identifying new therapeutic targets, so the correct category for this sentence is "Background".

934.source:
Given two entities as input, classify as "yes" if second entity is the part of the first entity. Otherwise classify them as "no". These are entities of meronym In linguistics, meronymy is a semantic relation between a meronym denoting a part and a holonym denoting a whole. In simpler terms, a meronym (i.e., second entity) is in a part-of relationship with its holonym (i.e., first entity).

Entity 1: speak word 
 Entity 2: packet
934.rationale: The first entity is "speak word", which refers to the ability of a person or animal to produce vocal sounds that enable communication by speech. Although there are many parts associated with this ability, including lips, tongue, larynx and lungs, none of these anatomical structures are referred to as “packet” (the second entity). Therefore, packet is not a meronym of speak word; rather it is part-of another related concept such as data packets transmitted through networks or communications systems.

935.source:
In this task, you are given an abstract of article. Your task is to generate label "True" if abstract is structured, otherwise generate "False". A structured abstract is composed of a topic sentence (or key sentence), relevant supporting sentences, and a closing (or transition) sentence. This structure is key to keeping your abstract focused on the main idea and creating a clear and concise image.

Next-generation sequencing technologies have greatly expanded our understanding of cancer genetics. Antisense technology is an attractive platform with the potential to translate these advances into improved cancer therapeutics, because antisense oligonucleotide (ASO) inhibitors can be designed on the basis of gene sequence information alone. Recent human clinical data have demonstrated the potent activity of systemically administered ASOs targeted to genes expressed in the liver. We describe the preclinical activity and initial clinical evaluation of a class of ASOs containing constrained ethyl modifications for targeting the gene encoding the transcription factor STAT3, a notoriously difficult protein to inhibit therapeutically. Systemic delivery of the unformulated ASO, AZD9150, decreased STAT3 expression in a broad range of preclinical cancer models and showed antitumor activity in lymphoma and lung cancer models. AZD9150 preclinical activity translated into single-agent antitumor activity in patients with highly treatment-refractory lymphoma and non–small cell lung cancer in a phase 1 dose-escalation study.
935.rationale: The abstract does not have a topic sentence that summarizes the main idea or objective of the study. It also does not include sentences about relevant supporting information or findings, and it ends with a statement rather than concluding sentence that summarizes main ideas. Therefore, this is an unstructured abstract.

936.source:

Clearly, if masked terms are important, the modified question will be impossible to answer. Please indicate the correct answer with one of the following responses: "A", "B", "C", "D" or "E". While "A"-"D" correspond to the answer options provided in the input, "E" represents "I don't know" for questions that do not provide enough information. Respond via "E" if the question is not answerable. Do not generate anything else apart from one of the following characters: 'A', 'B, 'C', 'D', 'E'.

Question: Which *** is *** for *** *** of *** *** and ***?  (A) digestive (B) urinary (C) locomotion (D) circulator.

Therefore, "E" should be selected as a response because enough information was not provided by the modified question to make an informed selection among options A-D.

940.source:
Read the given text and if it has abusive content then indicate via "yes". Otherwise indicate via"no". 
We consider the content to be abusive if it contains any of the following instances: (1) Identity Directed Abuse (e.g., Content which contains a negative statement made against an identity. An identity is a social category that relates to a fundamental aspect of individuals community, socio-demographics, position or self-representation) (2) Affiliation Directed Abuse (e.g., Content which express negativity against an affiliation. We define affiliation as a (more or less) voluntary association with a collective. Affiliations include but are not limited to: memberships (e.g. Trade unions), party memberships (e.g. Republicans), political affiliations (e.g. Right-wing people) and occupations (e.g. Doctors).) (3) Person Directed Abuse (e.g., Content which directs negativity against an identifiable person, who is either part of the conversation thread or is named. Person-directed abuse includes serious character based attacks, such as accusing the person of lying, as well as aggression, insults and menacing language.) and (4) Counter Speech (e.g., Content which challenges, condemns or calls out the abusive language of others.). Note that URLs in the text have been replaced with [Link].

979.source:
Garrett: I just feel like I can't keep everything inside anymore. I need to tell someone about the pressure I've been under.
Other person: It sounds like you've been through a lot lately. What's been going on?
Garrett: Well, my parents have been really pushing me to do well in school and get into a good college. They're always talking about how much money they spent on my education and how they expect me to make something of myself. But lately I've been feeling really overwhelmed and like I'm not good enough.
Other person: That sounds tough. Have you talked to your parents about how you're feeling?
Garrett: Yeah, but they just tell me that I need to try harder and that I'll never amount to anything if I don't get into a good school. They don't understand how much pressure I'm under. Sometimes I just feel like giving up altogether.
Other person: Garrett, it sounds like you're really struggling right now. But you shouldn't give up because your parents are putting pressure on you- everyone deals with some form of pressure in their life. What matters is how you deal with it. Maybe there are other ways to handle this situation that would be more productive for you?
Garrett: I don't know. I feel like I've tried everything and nothing seems to be working.
Other person: Well, let's brainstorm a few ideas together and see if we can come up with something that will help you feel better about the situation.
Literal:
979.target: Garrett starts to talk because Garrett wants to talk to someone.
979.rationale: The answer is "Garrett starts to talk because Garrett wants to talk to someone." The first person in the conversation (here after referred as Garrett) begins by expressing that he feels like he cannot keep everything inside anymore and needs to tell someone about the pressure he has been under. This can be interpreted literally as him just wanting a friend or some sort of confidant with whom they could discuss what's bothering them, hence the answer choice: "Garrett starts talking because Garrett wants to talk with somebody".

Braidyn: You're welcome, Santino. It's no problem, really.

Braidyn: Well, don't worry about it now. Everything's taken care of.

980.rationale: The narrative describes the details of a situation, in this case about how Santino's tire changed by Braidyn. The conversation between them is not giving any clue for what happened before and after their actual talk. However from the context it can be understood that they were talking about something specific around changing tires like "don't worry now" or "you're a lifesaver". So from these clues we can understand that Braidyn helped Santino to change his tire and he was glad with this help of him so that he could meet an appointment on time."

981.source:
In this task, you are given an narrative that includes an underlying commonsense knowledge and a part of the previous dialogue history grounded on the narrative. You have to guess the next response, which is highly related to the narrative.Narrative: Rianne gets more trouble. She feels guilty because she was caught stealing candy from the store.

Rianne: Hey, Mom. I'm sorry about what happened at the store today. I know I shouldn't have taken that candy without paying for it.
Mother: Rianne, what were you thinking? You know better than to steal. Now we're going to have to pay for the candy and you're going to be in big trouble.
Rianne: I know, Mom. I'm really sorry. It won't happen again.
Mother: This is not the first time something like this has happened, Rianne. You've been stealing a lot lately and I'm really getting concerned about it.
Rianne: Stealing's wrong, Mom. I know that. It's just...I don't know why I do it sometimes.
Mother: Well, we need to figure out why you're doing it and try to stop it from happening again. Maybe we can talk to your dad about it or get you some help from a counselor or something.
Rianne: Yeah, that might be a good idea...I'm sorry again, Mom.
Mother:
981.target: It's okay, sweetie. Just try to do better next time, okay?
981.rationale: The narrative shows that the mother is disappointed and angry because her daughter stole candy from a store, which made them have to pay for it. The chat history between Rianne and her mom also reflects this situation, where the mom expresses how upset she is about what happened at the store today. Therefore, when responding back after listening to everything Rianne said in response to getting caught stealing candy, her mom would most likely express that they need help figuring out why it keeps happening or even try speaking with someone like their dad or a counselor before making up with their child by saying something sweet like "It's okay".

In this task, you are given an narrative that includes an underlying commonsense knowledge and previous dialogue history grounded on the narrative. You have to generate an response which is also grounded by the narrative.
Narrative: Avah went to the store with the intention of buying a new pair of shoes. Upon arrival, Avah saw that the shoes he wanted were too expensive. Disappointed, Avah left the store without making a purchase.

Avah: Hi, I'm looking for a new pair of shoes.
Clerk: Yes, what type of shoes are you looking for?
Avah: I'm not really sure. Maybe something in black?
Clerk: We have a lot of different black shoes. Let me show you some of our options.
Avah: Ok.
Clerk: Here are some dress shoes that would be perfect for a night out or for work. They're very stylish and they're also very comfortable.
Avah: Yeah, they look nice but they're a little too expensive for me.
Clerk: That's ok. We have a lot of other options that are more affordable. Let me show you some of those.
Avah:
983.rationale: Avah went to the store with intention of buying a new pair of shoes. However, Avah didn't like any style that was available in his/her price range, so s/he left without making a purchase. In this conversation, while looking at different shoe styles, Avah said "Yeah they look nice but they're a little too expensive for me." This indicates that s/he is dissatisfied and doesn't want to buy anything because none of the options fit into her budget. So it's reasonable for him/her to leave after thanking the clerk by saying something like "Ok thanks."

997.source:
In this task, you are given an narrative that includes an underlying commonsense knowledge and previous dialogue history grounded on the narrative. You have to generate an response which is also grounded by the narrative.
Narrative: Alizabeth strives for perfection in everything she does, whether it's her schoolwork, her hobbies, or her relationships. Her drive for perfectionism often leaves her feeling anxious and stressed out, as she constantly compares herself to others and berates herself for not being good enough.

Alizabeth: I can't believe I got a B on that test. I'm such an idiot.
Sarah: Alizabeth, it's not a big deal. Everyone gets Bs sometimes.
Alizabeth: But I shouldn't get Bs. I should be getting As. I'm so behind everyone else.
Sarah: You're not behind anyone, Alizabeth. You're doing just fine.
Alizabeth: No, I'm not. I'm never going to amount to anything if I can't even get good grades.
Sarah: That's not true, and you know it. You're an amazing person with so much to offer the world, no matter what your grades are like. So please, try to relax and stop being so hard on yourself all the time, okay?
Alizabeth: I don't know if I can. It's just who I am.
Sarah: Well, maybe it's time for a change then. Just because you've always been a perfectionist doesn't mean you have to continue being one forever. Maybe it's time to give yourself a break and cut yourself some slack. What do you say?
Alizabeth: I don't know...I guess it couldn't hurt to try.
Sarah:
997.target: That's the spirit! I'm sure you'll be surprised at how much better you feel once you start letting go of your need to be perfect all the time.
997.rationale: The given narrative provides context about Alizabeth's personality and how she feels anxious, stressed out and compares herself to others as a result of her perfectionism. In the chat history, Sarah tries to convince Alizabeth that it is not necessary for her to be perfect all the time by being kind towards her. The most reasonable response in this case would involve encouraging or motivating Alizabeth into letting go of the need to strive for perfection at all times because she will start feeling better once she starts doing so. Hence, "That's the spirit! I'm sure you'll be surprised at how much better you feel once you start letting go of your need to be perfect all the time" is an appropriate answer choice here.

999.source:
Given a literal and previous dialogue history, generate the next response.
Literal: Giovanna tells Zeb to be silent because Giovanna wants to stop Zeb from talking.
Giovanna: What is going on? Why are you behaving so strangely?
Zeb: I don't know. I just feel really off today. Maybe it's something in the air.

Zeb: I don't know. I just feel really uncomfortable, like something bad is going to happen.
